awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A New Inverse Theory for Joint Parameter and Boundary Conditions Estimation to Improve Characterization of Deep Geologic Formations and Leakage Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
Eighty percent of U.S. energy demands are met by subsurface resources while deep geologic formations are also used as waste repository such as in the proposed actions of carbon storage. However, activities in deep zones have the potential to impact potable water in overlying shallow aquifers that is subject to contamination from leaking brine, hydraulic fracturing fluids, or gasses. Hence, to manage extraction and storage operations from deep reservoirs and to minimize the environmental impact on them, both an understanding of the processes that contribute to potential leakage and the methods to monitor such leakage are needed. This information helps to evaluate environmental risks and to assess corrective actions. The methods that are currently available for such understanding require extensive data collection from the subsurface which is very costly for deep formations. This research aims to develop an innovative method to integrate all available data from both shallow aquifers and often limited data from deep geologic zones to improve the monitoring of adverse environmental impacts. This new method, when validated in the laboratory, will use more easily available data from the shallow aquifers, thus reducing the need for costly drilling into deep formations. The new science that will be developed will allow for safer extraction of energy from deep formations and provide more secure subsurface storage of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, in order to mitigate global climate change that has potential human, ecological, and environmental impacts. The training opportunities associated with the execution of this research at two universities will contribute to scientific and technical human capacity building and new workforce development that will address emerging problems at the water-energy nexus.

The primary goal is to develop, and experimentally verify, a novel inverse theory that integrates limited data from deep formations with more abundant or easily obtainable shallow aquifer data for improved characterization of deep geologic zones as well as for the monitoring of connected, overlying aquifers for potential contamination. For data-poor subsurface systems, existing techniques that assume boundary conditions (BC) can result in non-unique and uncertain parameter estimates, leading to inaccurate models. Compared to the earlier techniques, the proposed theory does not use forward simulations to assess model-data misfits. Thus the knowledge of the difficult-to-determine site BC is not required. Instead, it imposes fluid flow and/or solute mass continuities conditioned to limited and noisy measurements. In this research, the theory will be further developed and tested by (1) inverting pressure and flow observations for hydraulic characterization of a deep formation, and (2) jointly inverting flow and water quality data for both deep zone characterization and leakage monitoring. This new theory, which is capable of simultaneous parameter and BC estimation, has been successfully tested with synthetic numerical data. Generation of accurate and comprehensive data for theory validation in the field is however not feasible. Thus, an approach that uses data from intermediate-scale laboratory testbeds is proposed. The experimental method allows for the creation of different aquifer heterogeneities in the laboratory and the accurate control of flow and transport initial and BC that emulate deep zone operations. The theory will be first tested by comparing parameters estimated using measurements made in a laboratory aquifer with accurately known parameters and BC. As a second step, hydraulic and tracer measurements will be made in a two-layered aquifer separated by a leaky aquitard. Data from both the shallow unconfined layer and the deep confined layer (i.e., source of the disturbance) will be jointly inverted to characterize the entire system and to identify leakage pathways and rates from the deep layer. The inversion algorithms will be validated by independent measurements from the same testbeds (i.e., fixed packing), but under different BC and leakage scenarios. After this validation, the theory will be demonstrated using synthetic data taken from a model representing a deep formation with geologically relevant parameters and conditions. The new method will aim to make characterization and monitoring more accurate and efficient for data-poor environments, making this research potentially transformational in both theory development and practical problem solution.

por.por_cntn:
The global energy demand during industrialization has been met mainly through the combustion of fossil fuels, resulting in a substantial rise in atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2), a greenhouse gas driving climate change. One of the methods that has been proposed for reducing gas loading is capturing and storing CO2 in deep geologic formations. One of the main technological challenges in implementing this technology is ensuring no leakage of the stored CO2 and formation brine occurs. If it ever happens, there is the potential of contaminating shallow aquifers used for potable water. The contamination risk comes from the brine and other toxic metals that get mobilized during such a leakage event. The EPA established the Underground Injection Control (UIC) program in 1980 to provide a regulatory framework for the protection of underground sources of drinking water (USDWs) from potential contamination risk. Under this program, a set of federal requirements regarding the planning, construction, and operation of CGS projects must be fulfilled to ensure efficient long-term trapping of injected CO2 and management of the potential leakages from geologic storage. These requirements include developing, implementing, and periodically reviewing the risk assessment analysis, monitoring system design, and emergency-remedial response plan (EPA, 2010). The broad goal of this project was to research to advance the science to develop tools to address this issue of safe carbon storage in deep geologic formations with a specific focus on leakage. 

The effectiveness of carbon storage and permanence depends on the hydrogeological conditions of the formation and the integrity of the confining caprock. Before mineralization, the injected supercritical CO2 in the liquid form goes through several phases.  The fluid displaces the brine, spreads, and gets trapped during injection. The trapped CO2 slowly dissolves in the brine in the formation. Both during the injection and dissolution phases, there is a potential risk of supercritical CO2 leaking through natural faults or caprock fractures induced by pressure buildup.  Such leakage events threaten both long-term storage permanence and introduce contamination risks.

The main challenge in managing and assessing the risk of such events at sites where leakage events have yet to transpire is the unavailability of data to test and validate the necessary tools, such as numerical models. The expected data will be sparse because testing and installing sensors at very high depths for geologic characterization and monitoring are costly. In contrast, relatively more significant amounts of data will still be available from the shallow formations.

Given these data challenges, the completed work has intellectual merits in contributing to addressing several key issues that are critical for the technology to be field implemented:

1. Uncertainties associated with incomplete knowledge of deep formation characteristics undermine the reliability of predicting contamination risks in the shallow zone. By acknowledging and tackling this issue, the work contributes to reducing such uncertainties.

2. The study proposes an integrated monitoring system that optimizes monitoring costs by combining low-cost shallow monitoring wells and sensors in the deep overlaying zones. This innovative approach ensures efficient monitoring while minimizing expenses.

3. When pressure buildup occurs during injection, the research develops pressure reduction schemes to mitigate contamination risks within regulatory limits. These schemes are proactive measures to lower potential impacts and safeguard against adverse consequences.

4. Recognition is given to the fact that the uncertainty regarding the location of a leakage and rates event contributes to contamination risks. To counter this, the work proposes utilizing less costly monitoring data from near-surface aquifers in the shallow zone to reduce the effect of such uncertainty to reasonable levels.

5. The limited knowledge regarding fracture network settings in the caprock poses challenges in accurately predicting the pathway and propagation of leakage in the shallow aquifer. By highlighting this issue, the work emphasizes the need for further research and improved understanding to enhance predictions and effectively address potential contamination risks.

To overcome some limitations of available field data, this work contributed to developing an innovative laboratory test system to conduct experiments to generate data with high spatial and temporal resolution under highly controlled conditions that are not feasible in the field.  The modeling tools validated using the generated were used to test scientific hypotheses to address the five practical issues mentioned above. 

The completed work has very broad impacts in addressing a highly societally significant problem of climate change and contributing to education by training graduate (two Ph.D.), and master’s and undergraduate (eleven, that included 3 female) students with skills in conducting complex experiments and developing advanced modeling methods. This research provides the designers and operators of carbon sequestration projects with tested and validated tools to enhance the risk management of these activities and meet the EPA safety requirements. This study's findings will help plan site characterization cost-efficiently and determine the best methods for field investigation during the early phases of carbon sequestration projects.
